Debunking for Dummies: alternative medicine

10/02/2015

What do you call alternative medicine which works? Medicine.

Image by

By undefined undefined

[caption id="attachment_118947" align="aligncenter" width="640"] The focus of this edition of Debunking for Dummies is, as you may have guessed , alternative medicine. People believe the craziest things when it comes to what makes them better, from having needles stuck in their back, to learning how to unlock the other 90 per cent of their brain. Homeopathy is an example of alternative medicine with a large following, but is so particularly ridiculous it will get its own article in weeks coming. Many proponents of alternative medicines insist that you disprove something in order for them to disbelieve it. The burden of proof, classic card to play. It annoys me. Technically, we cannot prove that dogs do not fly. There are, however, plenty of reasons to believe that they cannot fly. They lack the standard apparatus of flight; the aerodynamics aren't right; and it scoffs in the face of all observed canine behaviour ... but strictly speaking, we can't state that dogs do not fly. Not with certainty anyway. One day, we may discover they do, and also that unicorns exist, but until then there is no reason to believe it. The null hypothesis stands comfortably. There is sometimes good science laying hidden in depths of alternative treatments. People for centuries rubbed ground up willow bark on skin ailments to heal them. This isn't nonsense - the bark is a good source of salicylic acid, which acts in a similar way to aspirin. Instead of settling for grinding up a bark, the scientific community have researched, extracted and now produce aspirin, and even more effective painkillers. Science does not disregard all their practices, it just makes them better. One form of ridiculous of alternative medicine is Qigong. This is the belief whereby aligning the body, mind and breath can cure a vast array of diseases. It works on the basis of cultivating your "Chi" (life energy) and transferring it to areas in need of extra health. It sounds ridiculous, yet people believe that I will help them. Some who practice Qigong claim that is can cure cancer, and some - slightly less impressively - claim to lose weight using qigong. Losing weight probably will happen using Qigong; it is a form of exercise after all. The only concern is when the misinformed relinquish any help from conventional medicine in favour of Qigong therapy. There is only so much you can benefit from the placebo effect. [caption id="attachment_118949" align="aligncenter" width="640"] The placebo effect is a strange phenomenon. No one really knows how it works, but it can easily been shown in many different forms: from sugar pills to moaning at a GP, people tend to do better when they believe they are being cared for. The placebo effect is one of the strongest weapons "doctors" of alternative medicine have. There are plenty of theories as to why the placebo occurs but as of yet no one is really sure. Some people believe we have been classically conditioned to respond positively to healthcare. Like Pavlov's dog salivating upon hearing the bell, medical attention provides perceived relief of symptoms. Another theory is called the subject-expectancy effect. This states that because people already know the result of the treatment, they unconsciously change their reaction to bring about the result. The power of the mind is truly incredible. The reason treatments like homeopathy and acupuncture are so successful is that people who believe they work use them. People who don't trust them don't try them, and therefore they have a high percentage success rate. When you do trials with believers and non-believers, the results are starkly different. It has been shown in double blind tests that the results of a treatment are directly correlated to belief in it. That is the placebo in a nutshell. That is why practitioners of alternative medicine wear white coats and put a lot of effort into "dressing up" the treatment. Homeopathy has been shown only to be as effective as a placebo in studies. Although it is undeniable that the placebo effect does work, it is very dangerous to rely solely on it. It is fine to have acupuncture to relieve back pain, but drinking water with 10-60 parts "cure" in it is unlikely to work for anything worse than a mild cold. In conventional medicine, for a drug to pass testing it has to show "significantly greater" effects than the placebo control. This doesn't deter followers of homeopathy though. As to why the placebo works I am not sure we will ever get an answer, but I would rather have unanswerable questions than unquestionable answers.
